body:
- Enabled `ImportOrderChecker` and grouped all imports together as we do in Java. 
- Enabled `DisallowSpaceBeforeTokenChecker`.
- Let's ignore `NonASCIICharacterChecker`.

@rdblue `ReturnChecker` ensures that we don't have explicit return statements.
`ReturnChecker` doesn't sound like a good idea to me. Sometimes it's easier to use an explicit return and I see no reason to disallow it.
+1, that's the reason why I brought up this topic. Anything else to change?
Closing because it's done. Thanks @rdsr!
I agree, we should exclude all org.apache.hadoop dependencies in the runtime bundle.
Some of those are probably worth adding to Baseline proper - it seems bad to not have `ImportOrderChecker` for example. I'll file against Baseline in a bit.
Update description to reflect all hadoop dependencies

I've filed a jira for adding type annotations to ORC, please feel free to comment over there.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ORC-522

Please don't make a json file that needs to be parsed before opening up an ORC file in Iceberg. That is really slow and painful. Using the ORC file metadata is much much better since that means it stays in sync with the file.

Sorry about not getting back to the Iceberg ORC support to finish the schema evolution. It is unfortunate that Iceberg uses id-based schema evolution rather than using the name-based evolution that ORC natively supports. My original plan for ORC in Iceberg was to use the column ids to munge the column names so that ORC's schema evolution would do the right thing. So basically if the file had column "foo" as id 5 and the reader wanted "bar" as id 5, the Iceberg reader would munge the "bar" to "foo" and pass that down to ORC and then ORC's schema evolution would do the appropriate translations.

@omalley, I think the proposal is not to write separate JSON files. It is to embed the metadata in ORC's file-level properties. My point was that as long as we are encoding type ID and required/optional, we may as well just store the Iceberg schema that was used to write the file.
@rdblue The build passed. I learned to run `gradle check` locally (install to local Maven repo doesn’t do checks).
Thanks @electrum! Merged.

@electrum, can you give more context on where you need to use this? This is probably for create and replace operations in catalogs that aren't defined in Iceberg?

I'd prefer to move the static methods that are made public here to a `Transactions` class instead of making `BaseTransaction` public. I don't think there's a need to expose that class, just the factory methods.

I’m using this to create a `Transaction` instance directly, without using `BaseMetastoreTables` (as we have an alternate implementation).

Do you want a new `Transactions` class, or should they be static methods on the `Transaction` interface? The latter seems to be the favored way for Java 8 (it’s why they added static methods for interfaces).
@rdblue @rdsr thoughts on the above proposal?
I'll grab this
This should be fixed in #230?
@rdblue Have you already started working on this? If not, we can contribute this part if it doesn't depend on the catalog effort.
FYI. There's an PR out for metadata properties attached to Typedescription https://github.com/apache/orc/pull/410 . Thanks @omalley !
@electrum, we use the plural convention in most places to keep the interfaces cleaner, so I'd say use `Transactions`.

@aokolnychyi, this looks good to me except for the copyright header change. That needs to be reverted.

As for the problems that @rdsr noted, I'm okay fixing them either here or in a follow-up to keep this focused on baseline changes.
@aokolnychyi, FYI.

Thanks for the review @rdsr and @rdblue! Let's keep this PR Baseline-specific and I'll follow up with another PR to fix issues that @rdsr noted. +1 on them

@aokolnychyi, thanks for fixing this!

I made some of the suggested changes in #240. Let's get #240 and #239 in and then follow up with fixes for the remaining items.

Merged. Thanks @electrum!

I'm +1 for this, as long as it does not change expectations of the published artifacts. I don't want custom resolution in Iceberg to cause problems when including Iceberg in Presto, for example.

@electrum, any thoughts here?
LGTM
Minor comment. Other than that +1

I'm new to Gradle, but I read through the docs for `gradle-consistent-versions` and it seems quite reasonable. It has some nice features that I'd like to have in Maven. This appears to be a strict improvement over the current situation.

One problem this doesn't seem to solve is requiring dependency declarations for everything that is used directly. For example, before 37f6a20f324b23c26773b24259ee78d067d41323, the code was directly referencing `commons-compress`, but there was no direct dependency. The classes happened to be on the classpath via the `avro` dependency. This is solved in Maven via [`dependency:analyze`](https://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-dependency-plugin/usage.html#The_dependency:analyze_mojo). The Gradle equivalent seems to be [gradle-dependency-analyze](https://github.com/wfhartford/gradle-dependency-analyze) although I'm surprised there's not a more "official" solution.
@aokolnychyi, I merged #240, so could you rebase and update this to use HiveCatalog?
@rdblue @rdsr ready for another review round.

@rdblue What about cases when we drop tables from the catalog but keep the metadata? Will it make sense to have a way to register them back by giving a location?

It won't be straightforward, though. The location can be shared by multiple Iceberg tables and we also add a UUID to metadata file names in `BaseMetastoreTableOperations`.
Solved by adding relocate 'com.google.common', 'com.google.common.version28' in build.gradle.

Thanks for catching this, @jun-he! The footnotes plugin doesn't work well here because they are all added at the bottom of the spec in Appendix D. What about just moving the footnote text to the bottom of each section with "Note: "?
@HelloHorizon Where did you add this and were there any other steps? I'm facing the same issue. Thanks

@chris-alphonso For me, it is because of Guava version conflict. Since Spark v2.4.0 use 14.0.1 while iceberg use 28.0, you only need to add relocation for shardowjar in `build.gradle`. Add `relocate 'com.google.common', 'com.google.common.version28'` at line 415.
@aokolnychyi, can you take a look at this one?

@SurenNihalani and @rdsr, as part of adding user docs and testing with Spark 2.4, I updated the contents of the Spark runtime Jar last night and just opened #250. That work goes a bit beyond the scope of this PR because it removes any library already in Spark's `jars` folder, relocates all shaded classes, and cleans up some of the problems pointed out here.

It doesn't matter to me which PR we go with, but I think the changes from #250 are a good starting point because that cleans up this area quite a bit. Would you like to combine this PR and that one, or review that one and rebase to get this work in?

I'm not sure that we want to do this. The output of `toHumanString` should never be parsed. `withPartitionPath` is only intended to be used when adding files from Hive tables during conversion. In fact, we should probably separate it out into some sort of Hive util method in `iceberg-hive`.

Is there a use case for parsing Iceberg paths? I would assume not because Iceberg keeps partition values in metadata to avoid the need to ever parse them from a path.
@mccheah, @CRogers, this looks good to me other than the mockito problem that @rdsr pointed out. Can you address that comment?
Thanks for the updates, @edgarRd! I think this is getting close to merging.
[Here](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/0f55e50fe48c15a55b31277b48e70500c642ea50cf8d6a3f12dfafe4@%3Cdev.iceberg.apache.org%3E) is a relevant email thread on the dev list.
Sounds good to me. Lets review #250 and after #250 is committed, we can do the remaining work here if any.
@prodeezy is there an ETA for this feature to be completed?
Addressed that.

I agree with the idea to add a UUID to table metadata. I've been meaning to do that.

@vgankidi, it looks like this is based on an old version of your branch. Could you update it to the current?

@jun-he, using `!!! note` blocks adds a large call-out that isn't suitable for footnotes, which should not draw attention. Also, footnote links do not work if you aren't using the footnote plugin and show up in the doc like this: "buckets[^1]".

I recommend running `mkdocs serve` to see how these changes look locally before updating the PR. Also, there are other "Notes" sections that you can look at. Just match the formatting of those.
@rdblue @danielcweeks let me know you think about this.
Thanks for reviewing this, @rdsr and @aokolnychyi! I've merged it to unblock the other work in this area and docs.
@edgarRd, FYI. This PR has methods to truncate binary and string values to avoid writing huge stats in table metadata. Probably something you'll want to use for ORC.
Thanks for reviewing, @aokolnychyi! I'm going to merge this.
@rdsr and @SurenNihalani, I've merged #250 so this can continue. Thanks for being flexible on the conflict!

I'm not sure that it's a good idea to add Arrow to `iceberg-core` until there is more functionality there. Could we keep this as a PR until we know more about what the Arrow integration will look like? It would make sense as an add-on module like `iceberg-parquet` or `iceberg-orc`.
@rdblue Got it. I updated the PR accordingly and moved footnotes into the `Notes`. I ran the mkdocs server and it looked OK. Please let me know if you have any comments. Thanks!
@mccheah @rdblue do we actually need `hadoop.` data source options? Won't be enough to pick Hadoop configs from table properties?

I went ahead and added this recently in #246 to support overwrite in Spark 2.4 since it is taking a while to get 3.0 out. It should work the same way in 3.0, but we will no longer recommend using this API because it doesn't state the behavior sources should implement (overwrite, truncate, replace table are all allowed).

See the [overwrite docs](https://iceberg.apache.org/spark/#overwriting-data) and #246.

What problem does this fix? Isn't UTF-8 the default?

Thanks for working on this, @fbocse. I think it is a good idea to have a way to detects changes and prepare an update. But I think we need to be careful about some of the choices made in this commit:
* New features should be done in the core Java library so any client can use them, not just Spark
* It looks like this only detects new fields. What about fields that are removed? Also, using a Spark schema for detection means that this can't use schema IDs, so it can't tell the difference between a rename and a drop followed by add. That's probably another reason to build change detection between Iceberg schemas.
* Usually, we try to keep recursion logic and business logic separate by using the visitor pattern. I think that adding a visitor that traverses two Iceberg schemas at the same time, like the Parquet `TypeWithSchemaVisitor`, would help simplify the code and would be useful for other tasks.
@rdblue @rdsr one question: we define Jackson dependency as 2.7.9 but Spark 2.4.0 seems to use 2.6.7.1, which gives me `JsonMappingException` at runtime. Is my local config wrong?
Sorry for not getting back to this very quickly. I'm planning to review it this week.
